1.rationale:
Yo, chat, we’re live and I’m laser-focused on that rival snake at the top left—no time dawdling on apples, we’re trying to cage him in! 🎮👀

Let’s break it down: from (5,7) we can go UP to (5,8), DOWN to (5,6), LEFT to (4,7), or RIGHT to (6,7). None of our body or the enemy’s body is in those cells, so all moves are safe for now. But which one gives us the most control? I want to stay central while closing the net toward the enemy’s scuffed corner near (0,9). Going UP keeps me aligned with the top row and still allows quick pivots toward the left side later, whereas DOWN starts drifting into lower territory where we risk losing sight of him. Left would be decent for heading toward him, but I’d like to maintain vertical flexibility before committing. Right doesn’t help box him at all.

So I’m gonna push UP—keeps options open, keeps multiple follow-up moves, and starts me climbing toward the same space he’s trying to own. Let’s start building that wall.

Plan note for future self: Keep shadowing opponent’s trajectory toward the northwest corner, force him to waste space near the wall, then cut him off with a horizontal sweep once he’s committed. Keep tabs on apples only as they help extend territory; priority is closing on the enemy head and making the board smaller for him.

We need to think about the SIMULTANEOUS move. If we stay at (3,9) and he moves to (3,9), we both die. But we can't stay, we HAVE to move. Our only move is DOWN. So we vacate (3,9). The best outcome is if he does something STUPID and crashes.

Our move DOWN to (3,8) is safe and opens up future options. From (3,8) next turn, we can go LEFT, RIGHT, or DOWN. We can hunt the apple at (4,6) or (2,5). We're staying agile!
